skill.name: biopython
skill.description: Primary Python toolkit for molecular biology. Preferred for Python-based PubMed/NCBI queries (Bio.Entrez), sequence manipulation, file parsing (FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, PDB), advanced BLAST workflows, structures, phylogenetics. For quick BLAST, use gget. For direct REST API, use pubmed-database.
skill.summary: Primary Python toolkit for molecular biology. Preferred for Python-based PubMed/NCBI queries (Bio.En...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill that provides comprehensive information about Biopython, a legitimate bioinformatics Python library. The skill contains no executable code, network calls, file operations, or security-sensitive capabilities. It consists entirely of educational content and code examples for bioinformatics analysis.

content.value_statement: Biopython skill provides comprehensive documentation for computational molecular biology tasks. It helps researchers and bioinformaticians analyze DNA, RNA, and protein sequences using Python's most popular bioinformatics library.
actual_capabilities: Provides detailed documentation for Bio.Seq and Bio.SeqIO modules
Explains sequence alignment algorithms and BLAST operations
Documents NCBI database access via Bio.Entrez
Covers phylogenetic tree analysis and visualization
Details protein structure analysis with Bio.PDB
Includes advanced features like motifs and population genetics
limitations: NCBI database access needs internet connection
Some features require external tools (DSSP, BLAST+)
Large sequence files may need memory optimization

use_cases.title: Analyze DNA sequences and find genes
use_cases.description: Read FASTA files, calculate GC content, translate DNA to protein, and identify open reading frames in genomic sequences.

use_cases.title: Build phylogenetic trees
use_cases.description: Create multiple sequence alignments, calculate distance matrices, and construct neighbor-joining trees for evolutionary analysis.

use_cases.title: Search NCBI databases
use_cases.description: Query PubMed for literature, fetch sequences from GenBank, and run BLAST searches to find homologous sequences.

prompt_templates.title: Basic sequence analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a FASTA file with DNA sequences. How do I read it with Biopython and calculate the GC content for each sequence?

prompt_templates.title: Protein structure analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: I downloaded a protein structure from PDB. How can I extract the amino acid sequence and calculate distances between specific residues?

prompt_templates.title: BLAST search workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a nucleotide sequence and want to find similar sequences in the NCBI database. Show me how to run a BLAST search and parse the results.

prompt_templates.title: Phylogenetic analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: I have multiple protein sequences from different species. How do I create a multiple sequence alignment and build a phylogenetic tree to show their evolutionary relationships?

output_examples.input: How do I read a FASTA file and get basic sequence statistics?
output: Use Bio.SeqIO.parse() to read FASTA files:

best_practices: Always set Entrez.email when accessing NCBI databases
Use iterators for large files to save memory
anti_patterns: Don't load entire large files into memory at once
Avoid hardcoding file paths in reusable code
Don't ignore error handling for network operations
Never skip setting email for NCBI queries

faq.question: Is Biopython compatible with Python 3?
faq.answer: Yes, Biopython 1.85 supports Python 3 and requires NumPy as a dependency.

faq.question: What file formats does Biopython support?
faq.answer: Biopython supports FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, PDB, mmCIF, Clustal, Newick, and many other bioinformatics formats.

faq.question: Can I use this skill without internet connection?
faq.answer: Yes, for local file analysis. However, NCBI database access and BLAST searches require internet connectivity.

faq.question: How do I handle large sequence files?
faq.answer: Use SeqIO.parse() as an iterator, SeqIO.index() for random access, or low-level parsers for high-throughput data.

faq.question: What's the difference between this and gget skill?
faq.answer: Biopython is for comprehensive Python-based analysis, while gget provides quick command-line access to databases.

faq.question: Do I need programming experience?
faq.answer: Basic Python knowledge helps, but the skill provides detailed examples you can adapt for your needs.
